parent.body:
With Obama and the Bush neocons, the country moved further away from limited government and individual rights. That doesn't just mean that those administrations didn't believe in those things, it means that under those administrations the laws and legislation that was passed moved in that direction and so did the regulations that executive branch agencies imposed on the country. Those things remain in effect after those administrations are gone. 

What the media labels as, and what you seem to believe is, conservatives being more "far-right" than they were in the past is simply people on the right trying to move us back towards where we were in like the year 2000. That's the kind of fighting back that I'm talking about.  When politicians do things that the media disagrees it's typical for them to try to depict those actions as authoritarian. They're basically making a kind of procedural argument that legislation that the media agrees with should not be changed unless there is a massive public mandate from lots of politicians winning elections based on their promise to do so.

post.body:
It's undeniable that the central tenets of the (US) conservatives used to be small, limited government, states rights, individual liberty, free markets, free speech, etc. With a few exceptions (such as the war on drugs and the death penalty), conservatives were basically a more moderate version of libertarian, and there was a lot of spillover from one to the other.

However in the past few years that has definitely changed. I haven't seen it in its purest form since about a decade ago or maybe even before that, but it's really picked up in the past 1-2 years. Conservatives are now suddenly demanding a strong state, control of the people, censorship, tough laws banning things they determined have a negative impact on society, more restricted individual rights, etc. They've basically become the left with a right-wing agenda. This was a really fast change and it's been shocking to me; I still have trouble believing it. What's the hardest is seeing all my conservative friends changing at once and suddenly going from mostly believers in freedom to solid authoritarians in a really short time. Their fundamental philosophy is such the opposite of what it was, and to me this major shift in thinking is a complete mystery. Ironically, they now closely resemble Joe Biden in his younger days of politics. Of course I still know of many people who believe in the old philosophy, but the majority of their former allies no longer do and now regard them as traitors. I can't wrap my head around what's going on here. Big brother is now watching you from both sides. So to the current conservatives out there, what made you decide this is necessary?
post.body_html:
It's undeniable that the central tenets of the (US) conservatives used to be small, limited government, states rights, individual liberty, free markets, free speech, etc. With a few exceptions (such as the war on drugs and the death penalty), conservatives were basically a more moderate version of libertarian, and there was a lot of spillover from one to the other.

However in the past few years that has definitely changed. I haven't seen it in its purest form since about a decade ago or maybe even before that, but it's really picked up in the past 1-2 years. Conservatives are now suddenly demanding a strong state, control of the people, censorship, tough laws banning things they determined have a negative impact on society, more restricted individual rights, etc. They've basically become the left with a right-wing agenda. This was a really fast change and it's been shocking to me; I still have trouble believing it. What's the hardest is seeing all my conservative friends changing at once and suddenly going from mostly believers in freedom to solid authoritarians in a really short time. Their fundamental philosophy is such the opposite of what it was, and to me this major shift in thinking is a complete mystery. Ironically, they now closely resemble Joe Biden in his younger days of politics. Of course I still know of many people who believe in the old philosophy, but the majority of their former allies no longer do and now regard them as traitors. I can't wrap my head around what's going on here. Big brother is now watching you from both sides. So to the current conservatives out there, what made you decide this is necessary?
post.title: Conservatives, why have you forsaken libertarianism in the past few years?

body:
And that was the founding principles of the United States, and exactly why supporters of it were called "conservative" because they believed in keeping these values.

I will note though, that I think you both are falling into a common misconception of what anarchy is. It's not all mob rule and no rules, it just means no central authority. There would still be police and defense against aggression and coercion and force; the only difference is that it would be through voluntary measures and competitive. In fact you could argue that the earth itself is ancap, the difference being that the differences are between geographic location rather than individuals.

parent.body:
What you're describing sounds more like anarchy than liberatarianism. 

Liberatarianism is about keeping the government in check, but still present. The government is a useful tool, but it shouldn't be a consuming central aspect of everyone's life. The ideal is that the government is run in such a way that only truly nefarious, I'll willed individuals have to fear it. It should be strong enough to protect citizens from entities (foreign and domestic) who wish to harm or enslave said citizens in any way, but it should be gentle enough that people have the ability to achieve the life they choose (so long as it doesn't directly harm others) without constant government interference.

It's about striking a balance.
parent.body_html:
What you're describing sounds more like anarchy than liberatarianism.

Liberatarianism is about keeping the government in check, but still present. The government is a useful tool, but it shouldn't be a consuming central aspect of everyone's life. The ideal is that the government is run in such a way that only truly nefarious, I'll willed individuals have to fear it. It should be strong enough to protect citizens from entities (foreign and domestic) who wish to harm or enslave said citizens in any way, but it should be gentle enough that people have the ability to achieve the life they choose (so long as it doesn't directly harm others) without constant government interference.

It's about striking a balance.

post.body:
It's undeniable that the central tenets of the (US) conservatives used to be small, limited government, states rights, individual liberty, free markets, free speech, etc. With a few exceptions (such as the war on drugs and the death penalty), conservatives were basically a more moderate version of libertarian, and there was a lot of spillover from one to the other.

However in the past few years that has definitely changed. I haven't seen it in its purest form since about a decade ago or maybe even before that, but it's really picked up in the past 1-2 years. Conservatives are now suddenly demanding a strong state, control of the people, censorship, tough laws banning things they determined have a negative impact on society, more restricted individual rights, etc. They've basically become the left with a right-wing agenda. This was a really fast change and it's been shocking to me; I still have trouble believing it. What's the hardest is seeing all my conservative friends changing at once and suddenly going from mostly believers in freedom to solid authoritarians in a really short time. Their fundamental philosophy is such the opposite of what it was, and to me this major shift in thinking is a complete mystery. Ironically, they now closely resemble Joe Biden in his younger days of politics. Of course I still know of many people who believe in the old philosophy, but the majority of their former allies no longer do and now regard them as traitors. I can't wrap my head around what's going on here. Big brother is now watching you from both sides. So to the current conservatives out there, what made you decide this is necessary?

parent.body:
Libertarians claim that more freedom leads to a more economically prosperous society and they have convincing arguments to support their position. Conservatives tend to agree, but at the same time they understand that there are consequences to freedom that libertarians either ignore or downplay. These very freedoms that are theoretically supposed to bring about a libertarian utopia are also the ones that are undermining our society.

The freedom of women to vote leads to women voting for bigger government.

Education for women is highly correlated with plummeting birth rates.

Birth control and its consequences have been a disaster for the white race.

Promiscuity is highly damaging to women, leading to inability to pair-bond and skyrocketing divorce rates.

What good are freedoms if they lead to a failing society on the verge of invasion, collapse and genocide?

I can't wrap my head around what's going on here. Big brother is now watching you from both sides. So to the current conservatives out there, what made you decide this is necessary?

body:
Only a decade or two ago, conservative was basically just a term for a political moderate leaning libertarian. They believed strongly in limited government and individual rights (with a few exceptions). It was called "conservative" because that's the governance that the US has its roots in. But now their focus has shifted more to cracking down on everything they believe is plaguing society and threatening "traditional values", more akin to the conservatives and loyalists of revolutionary times. The leftist media has always made these claims but I can attest that it was complete bullshit...until the last couple of years (though it's still nowhere near as extreme as they try to say it is).

I don't usually trust the media's statistics data, but I know from personal experience that new membership in the Republican party is indeed lower than ever, and keeps going down. Most people I know just can't get behind this new authright stuff any more than they feel comfortable backing leftist SJWs and the media (but the media constantly advocates the Democratic party so it still gets new support). Even I feel like this, as I used to agree with conservatives on most things because we had similar beliefs, and the conservative-libertarian alignment was well-known across the board, but that's no longer the case.

Unpopular opinion: True libertarianism is just as fragile and unachievable of a concept as communism is. Both utterly collapse when exposed to real world realities. Both are equally susceptible to corruption and ignore human nature.

Communism doesn't work because it fails to acknowledge the human trait of individualism or what some may call "selfishness".

Libertarianism doesn't work because there will any amount of power given to anybody to govern (by consent or not) will grow exponentially and keeping it in check takes a level of moral courage that human beings really don't have.

Mind, when I refer to each ideology, I refer to them in their "perfect" or "purest" forms.

body:
I've seen a large uptick of it in mainly two categories:

* Unpatriotic expression such as flag burning, or extremely unconservative views (ie. communism, much like the left tries to censor extreme conservatism)

* Anything considered "degenerate" or offensive to tradition

Of course some of these have been banned at points in the distant past too (I believe mostly by Democrats actually, like Joe Biden) but in general it's been more of a distaste for them (often quite understandably). I don't think anyone I know would argue for these things being illegal until very recently because individual freedom was always very important to them before, but now many of them are demanding that it be forcefully dealt with.

post.body:
It's undeniable that the central tenets of the (US) conservatives used to be small, limited government, states rights, individual liberty, free markets, free speech, etc. With a few exceptions (such as the war on drugs and the death penalty), conservatives were basically a more moderate version of libertarian, and there was a lot of spillover from one to the other.

However in the past few years that has definitely changed. I haven't seen it in its purest form since about a decade ago or maybe even before that, but it's really picked up in the past 1-2 years. Conservatives are now suddenly demanding a strong state, control of the people, censorship, tough laws banning things they determined have a negative impact on society, more restricted individual rights, etc. They've basically become the left with a right-wing agenda. This was a really fast change and it's been shocking to me; I still have trouble believing it. What's the hardest is seeing all my conservative friends changing at once and suddenly going from mostly believers in freedom to solid authoritarians in a really short time. Their fundamental philosophy is such the opposite of what it was, and to me this major shift in thinking is a complete mystery. Ironically, they now closely resemble Joe Biden in his younger days of politics. Of course I still know of many people who believe in the old philosophy, but the majority of their former allies no longer do and now regard them as traitors. I can't wrap my head around what's going on here. Big brother is now watching you from both sides. So to the current conservatives out there, what made you decide this is necessary?

body:
> Where are you getting this? There's a fringe of social conservatism that has always demanded a strong state. They're still a fringe. They're usually the muppets that back whatever neocon rino bullshit that the usual faces push. They're the support base that helped bush get into Iraq. They're useful idiots.

These types have always existed but they were an extreme minority (I can't say I had ever even met one in real life before). Now they're becoming the majority.

> Most "conservatives" are actually just libertarians. If anything, the push is the opposite of what you're stating.

That's how it was until recently, as I said. But most of them are now shifting toward authoritarian.

> The Tea Party movement brought libertarian ideas into mainstream politics, prior to that the conservatives accepted gun control measures and foreign interventionism.

It was definitely long before that. The Republican Party has favored weak federal government and individual freedom for at least a century, even though there were exceptions for a few specific issues (which have changed over time). Indeed:

> If you analyze it I believe the very heart and soul of conservatism is libertarianism. I think conservatism is really a misnomer just as liberalism is a misnomer for the liberals ‚Äî if we were back in the days of the Revolution, so-called conservatives today would be the Liberals and the liberals would be the Tories. The basis of conservatism is a desire for less government interference or less centralized authority or more individual freedom and this is a pretty general description also of what libertarianism is.

‚Äî Ronald Reagan

> Now the true small government conservatives control the party rhetoric

I haven't paid much attention to the Republican Party, but my experience has been the opposite in regards to both people I know personally and popular figures.

> What you might be seeing among friends is something ive theorized and seen others allude to, I call it "overtones window stretching" but there's probably a better name. Basically, when the left shifts further left towards authoritarianism, the normal people start to get scared, become more accepting of drastic measures to prevent it and there is a reactionary shift towards more authoritarian conservatism. An example of this would be the rise of Pinochet. You can see throughout history, the rise of "fascism" and similar movements are always reactionary to socialist movements, I have yet to find a single example of any perceivable "right wing authoritarian" movement that was not a reaction to leftist incursions on a society.

I actually thought of that too and tend to agree, but I figured it'd be good to hear firsthand what caused people to change their mind.

You can see throughout history, the rise of "fascism" and similar movements are *always* reactionary to socialist movements, I have yet to find a single example of any perceivable "right wing authoritarian" movement that was not a reaction to leftist incursions on a society.

body:
> I think you need to find out how YOU are uniquely special

That's the thing, I'm not. I'm just ok at everything and that's as far as I will ever get. I have no strengths or advantages of my own. Even if I do, which I haven't seen any of yet, it must be something I hate doing. Yet these other people are automatically perfect, and I mean *perfect* at not just one or two things, but nearly *everything*. The stuff I've been obsessed with for years, they will blow me away just starting out or barely being interested in it. And I'm not even good enough at anything to accomplish barely anything decent at all, let alone with almost no faults at all in such little amount of time with such little experience. They all have everything together and figured out and everything falls apart for me no matter what I try.

guild.description:
A Ruqqus guild for collecting materials which promote positive changes in your life and the lives of others. Life skills, goals, and motivation are all here. We spend lots of time knocking each other down, and getting into heated discussions, so this is a place for improving yourself.

I'm pretty lax with rules, just don't go around calling people insults. Self-improvement stories, questions, and discussions are allowed. Members are encouraged to build each other up, and save each other from blackpill and doomer mentalities. This guild is a place for positivity, so we can break out of negative thinking and stop blackpilling ourselves.
